title: Communications on Internet - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Computer Science - Module 1: Lesson 6

questions.question: What is Internet?
options: Network of networks connecting millions of computers globally
questions.explanation: Internet is a vast communication network which connects thousands and millions of computers across the globe. It is called network of networks because it is made up of thousands of smaller networks.

questions.question: What is needed to connect to the Internet?
options: Web browser, modem, telephone connection, and ISP connection
questions.explanation: To connect to Internet, we need: (i) A web browser installed on our computer, (ii) A modem, (iii) A telephone connection, and (iv) A connection from an Internet Service Provider (ISP).

questions.question: What does ARPANET stand for?
questions.explanation: ARPANET stands for Advanced Research Projects Agency Network. It was created by the Department of Defence in USA to protect government communication systems.

questions.question: Who created ARPANET?
questions.explanation: The Department of Defence in USA created ARPANET to protect government communication systems in the event of a military strike.

questions.question: What are the rules to communicate on Internet called?
questions.explanation: Internet uses certain rules called protocols which allow sharing of resources among various users on the network.

questions.question: What is a webpage?
options: A document that can be viewed in a web browser
questions.explanation: The document that can be viewed in the web browser is known as the web page.

questions.question: What is a website?
options: Collection of web pages interlinked through hyperlinks
questions.explanation: The collection of web pages interlinked with each other through hyperlinks is known as website. The first page of a website is known as the home page.

questions.question: What is the first page of a website called?
questions.explanation: The first page of a website is known as the home page.

questions.question: What does WWW stand for?
questions.explanation: WWW stands for World Wide Web, which is a system of Internet servers that support documents formatted using HTML.

questions.question: What is a web browser?
options: Free software application to view web pages and online content
questions.explanation: A web browser is a free software application that is used to view web pages, graphics and almost any other online content. It helps us to navigate through the World Wide Web.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a web browser?
questions.explanation: Microsoft Word is a word processing application, not a web browser. Common browsers include Internet Explorer, Firefox, Google Chrome, Netscape Navigator and Safari.

questions.question: What is a web server?
options: Server on WWW that responds to requests made by web browsers
questions.explanation: A web server is the server on the World Wide Web that responds to the request made by the web browsers.

questions.question: What does URL stand for?
questions.explanation: URL stands for Uniform Resource Locator. It specifies the unique address assigned to each web resource (webpage, video, image, song etc.).

questions.question: In the URL format 'type://address/path', what does 'type' specify?
options: The type of server or protocol
questions.explanation: In a URL, 'type' specifies the type of server or protocol, 'address' specifies the name/address of the server, and 'path' specifies the location of file on the server.

questions.question: What does the domain name '.com' indicate?
questions.explanation: .com domain name is used for commercial firms/companies/organizations.

questions.question: What does the domain name '.edu' indicate?
questions.explanation: .edu domain name is used for educational organizations.

questions.question: What does IP stand for in IP address?
questions.explanation: IP stands for Internet Protocol. Every computer on the network has a unique IP address for identification and tracking purposes.

questions.question: How many parts does an IP address typically have?
questions.explanation: An IP address is a four-part or eight-part electronic serial number with each part separated by dots (.) or colons (:). For example, '212.30.0.220'.

questions.question: What does HTML stand for?
questions.explanation: HTML stands for Hyper Text Markup Language, which defines how web pages are formatted and displayed in the web browser.

questions.question: What is HTML?
options: A markup language that uses tags to define page layout
questions.explanation: HTML is a markup language that specifies the web page layout and hyperlinks through special layout commands called tags. It is neither a programming language nor a word processor.

questions.question: What does XML stand for?
questions.explanation: XML stands for Extensible Markup Language, which is used to display content in a structured, human-readable and machine-readable format.

questions.question: What is the main difference between HTML and XML?
options: HTML defines display, XML assigns meaning to elements
questions.explanation: HTML defines how elements are displayed and printed while XML assigns meaning to the elements. HTML uses predefined tags while XML requires developers to define most tags.

questions.question: What does ISP stand for?
questions.explanation: ISP stands for Internet Service Provider. It is a private company or government agency that offers services like viewing web pages, emailing, hosting websites, etc.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an ISP?
questions.explanation: Airtel is an Internet Service Provider (ISP). Other examples include MTNL and TataDocomo.

questions.question: What does TCP/IP stand for?
questions.explanation: TCP/IP stands for Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol. It is the basic protocol suite of the Internet.

questions.question: What does the TCP part of TCP/IP do?
options: Breaks message into packets and reassembles them
questions.explanation: The TCP part handles the message by breaking it into small units called packets, transmitting them, and reassembling them at the receiver. It also retransmits lost data.

questions.question: What does the IP part of TCP/IP do?
options: Assigns unique IP addresses and ensures data reaches correct destination
questions.explanation: The IP part assigns a unique IP address to each recipient and ensures that data is transmitted to the correct destination.

questions.question: What does FTP stand for?
questions.explanation: FTP stands for File Transfer Protocol. It defines the set of rules to transfer any type of file on a TCP/IP based network.

questions.question: What does HTTP stand for?
questions.explanation: HTTP stands for Hyper Text Transfer Protocol. It is the set of rules used to transfer hypertext on World Wide Web.

questions.question: What does HTTPS provide that HTTP doesn't?
options: Encryption layer to secure personal information and passwords
questions.explanation: HTTPS (Hyper Text Transfer Protocol Secured) adds a special layer of encryption to hide user's personal information and passwords. It's used by ecommerce sites for secure transactions.

questions.question: What is Email?
questions.explanation: Email or Electronic mail refers to the messages sent electronically via Internet. These messages travel through multiple channels to reach their destination.

questions.question: What is Instant Messaging (IM)?
questions.explanation: Instant Messaging (IM) is an Internet service that allows us to communicate with people instantaneously, generally through text-based messaging, though voice chat is also popular.

questions.question: Which of the following is an Instant Messaging service?
questions.explanation: Skype is an Instant Messaging service. Other examples include Yahoo Messenger, Hike Messenger, and Google Talk.

questions.question: What is a chat room?
options: Online web service where two or more users send messages in real time
questions.explanation: A chat room is an online web service in which two or more users can send messages to each other in real time, engaging in text, voice or video-based live discussions.

questions.question: What is a newsgroup?
options: Public forum where users exchange information about a particular topic
questions.explanation: A newsgroup is like a public forum where multiple users continuously exchange information about a particular topic. Messages are posted on a bulletin board.

questions.question: What does the word 'blog' come from?
questions.explanation: The word 'blog' was coined by Peter Merholz in 1999 and comes from 'Web Log.' It's a website containing online personal journal with comments and reflections.

questions.question: What is blogging?
options: Process of authoring or editing a blog
questions.explanation: The process of authoring or editing a blog is called blogging. Each individual article posted is known as a blog post.

questions.question: What are blogs created and edited by multiple users called?
questions.explanation: Blogs which are created and edited by multiple users are known as Multi Author Blogs (MABs).

questions.question: What is microblogging?
options: Type of blogging with only short messages
questions.explanation: Microblogging is the type of blogging in which only short messages are posted. Twitter is a commonly used website for microblogging.

questions.question: What is Twitter also known as?
questions.explanation: Twitter is known as 'SMS of the Internet' because users can send and receive maximum of 140 characters in a text message called tweets.

questions.question: Who created Twitter?
questions.explanation: Twitter was created in 2006 by Jack Dorsey. It's a microblogging platform where messages are called tweets.

questions.question: What is Video Conferencing?
options: Technology allowing communication via simultaneous two-way audio and video
questions.explanation: Video Conferencing (VC) is technology that allows communication between two or more people at different locations by simultaneous two-way audio and video or text transmissions.

questions.question: What are the three main types of video conferencing?
questions.explanation: The three main types of video conferencing technologies are: Point to Point (direct connection between two locations), Multipoint (virtual conference room), and Streaming (via web browser or mobile).

questions.question: What is social networking?
options: Internet service allowing people to build social relations online
questions.explanation: Social networking is an Internet service that allows people to build social relations on the net, sharing common interests or having real-life connections to form online communities.

questions.question: Which is the most commonly used social networking website?
questions.explanation: Facebook is the most commonly used social networking site today with over one billion active users.

questions.question: Who founded Facebook?
questions.explanation: Facebook was founded by Mark Zuckerberg on 4th February, 2004. Initially it was restricted to Harvard University students but now allows anyone over 13 years old.

questions.question: What is a cookie in web terminology?
options: Message given to web browser by web server, stored in text file
questions.explanation: A cookie is the message given to the web browser by a web server. The message is stored in a text file and sent back to the server each time the browser requests a page.

questions.question: Can cookies spread viruses?
options: No, they cannot access hard drive or spread viruses
questions.explanation: Cookies cannot access the hard drive of our computer, so they are not capable of spreading viruses. They are neither plug-ins nor malicious programs.

questions.question: What does 'cloud' signify in Cloud Computing?
questions.explanation: In Cloud computing, the word 'cloud' signifies Internet. Cloud computing means Internet-based computing where services are delivered through Internet.

questions.question: What does Cloud Computing rely on?
options: Sharing resources rather than storing on local servers or devices
questions.explanation: Cloud computing relies on sharing resources (such as data and applications) rather than storing them on local servers or personal devices. Services are delivered via Internet.
